metadata.title: THE COVID-19 HOTEL FOR HEALTHCARE WORKERS: AN ITALIAN BEST PRACTICE

body_text.text: At the time of COVID19 pandemic, some healthcare workers (HCWs), directly involved in the assistance of infectious patients, chose a temporary separation from their family, to protect their parents or children from the epidemic risk. Such separation can very difficult and expensive. In China, some hospitals provided such facilities, which included provision of food and daily living supplies, and help for staff to video record their routines in the hospital to share with their families to alleviate family members' concerns. 1 We describe our experience of providing a similar facility in southern Italy.
The Bari Policlinico General Hospital is the most important hospital in southern Italy, and part of the COVID-19 hospital network (300 beds for COVID-19 patient). 656 HCWs worked in COVID-19 wards.

From April, 1 st 2020, the HI Hotel in Bari offered to accommodate HCWs employed in the COVID-19 area of the hospital for one month. The hotel is a 4-star hotel establishment with 88 rooms that normally provides facilities for meetings and accommodates both tourists and business travellers.

Prior to April 1 st an inspection was carried out by the Occupational Physician and the Prevention-Protection Service Manager, to plan the procedures aimed at avoiding the spread of SARS-CoV-2 in the hotel. The "COVID Hotel" provided a"dirty paths" -reserved for HCWs -to regulate entry and exit to and from the building. Specific rules of behaviors were defined to limit all possible contacts between the guest HCWs and the staff.

The "HCWs way" provided specific elevators to access to upper floors reserved for HCWs. The elevators were programmed for single lift travels, to avoid contact between different persons. This procedure is consistent with previous experience in some hospitals with zero cases of nosocomial COVID-19. 2 HCW had to reach the hotel on foot or by car. Specific horizontal signage directed HCWs to a pre-triage room for a temperature check, and to answer to questionnaire about signs and symptoms of COVID-19 (i.e. fever, weakness, cough, shortness of breath, muscle pain, anosmia, ageusia, etc.). Persons with temperature >37.5°C or reporting specific signs or symptoms were evaluated by physicians. 3 During the check-in, HCW received the electronic key of his room and instructions about meals. The restaurant was closed to avoid close contact between guests. Of note, a cluster of COVID-19 in a restaurant, involving three families, has been described in China. 3 Meals were delivered to outside each room to further avoid contact between hotel staff and HCWs.

Each room was provided with an appropriate double bag for garbage; the bag must be closed by the HCW to avoid the contact between waste and staff. Garbage was managed according to rules for biological waste at infectious risk. 4 Hotel staff undertaking meal delivery, cleaning and waste transfer used appropriate gloves and a medical mask.

HCWs had to stay inside their rooms. To enter common areas (such as the hall), the use of medical mask and shoes covers was mandatory; all HCWs were trained on the correct use of the medical masks. 5 The rooms were only cleaned when the HCW was not in the room. Cleaning of common areas (i.e. corridors, lifts) can be carried out at various times, but avoiding the hours of the day when HCWs go or come back to the hospital (around 07.00 and 14.00). Cleaners had to wear Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), such as double gloves, Filtering Face Piece FFP2 and disposable shoe covers, taking care to replace both the latter and the outer gloves before entering each room. During cleaning, disposable single-use equipment was used where possible. 6 In the COVID 19 Hotel, 23 HCWs 21 nurses and 2 physicians) were lodged. They came from Infectious Disease Ward, Emergency Room and Critical Care Areas; 12 were female and the average age was Hospital. Nasopharyngeal swabs were collected as recommended by CDC. 7 Diagnostic procedures 4 were according to WHO recommendations. 8 No cases of asymptomatic carriers of SARS-CoV-2 were detected. With careful planning, and excellent staff cooperation, HCWs can be safely hosted in hotel facilities during the COVID-19 pandemic
